definitions: express or communicate something using particular language or terms
formulate or phrase something in a particular manner or style
examples: She carefully worded her response to avoid any misunderstanding
The lawyer worded the contract to protect his client's interests
How should I word this invitation to sound more formal?
The poet worded each verse with deliberate care and precision

definitions: engage in physical or mental activity to achieve a purpose or result
operate or function effectively as intended or expected
shape or manipulate material through effort or artistic skill
have the desired influence or produce the intended effect
solve or calculate a mathematical problem through systematic steps
examples: She works at the hospital from Monday through Friday
The construction crew worked through the night to finish the project
My old computer still works perfectly after ten years
The new medication seems to work better than expected
The sculptor works the clay into beautiful forms and shapes
She worked the dough until it became smooth and elastic
That strategy won't work with such stubborn opposition
His charm always works on the interview panel members
Can you work this equation to find the unknown variable?
The students worked through all the practice problems together

definitions: move or progress slowly with twisting or crawling movements
extract information or oneself gradually through persistent effort
treat an animal to remove parasitic worms from its system
examples: The spy wormed through the narrow ventilation shaft
He slowly wormed his way through the crowded concert venue
She eventually wormed the truth out of her reluctant witness
He wormed his way into their exclusive social circle
The veterinarian wormed all the puppies before adoption
You should worm your horses twice a year minimum

definitions: feel anxious or troubled about actual or potential problems
cause someone to feel anxious or concerned about something
tear at or gnaw something persistently with the teeth
examples: She worries constantly about her children's safety at school
Don't worry about the test results until they arrive
The rising crime rate worries many residents in the neighborhood
It worries me that he hasn't called in three days
The dog worried the old bone for hours in the backyard
The wolf worried at the carcass until dawn approached slowly

definitions: cause something to deteriorate or become more severe or serious
deteriorate or become more severe, serious, or unfavorable over time
examples: The new policies will only worsen the economic situation further
His careless comments worsened the already tense atmosphere considerably
The patient's condition worsened overnight despite intensive medical treatment
Weather conditions are expected to worsen throughout the weekend

definitions: show reverence and adoration for a deity through religious practices
love, admire, or respect someone or something greatly or excessively
examples: They worship at the temple every Sunday morning without fail
Ancient civilizations worshipped many different gods and goddesses together
She absolutely worships her older brother despite his many flaws
The fans worship the ground their favorite celebrity walks on

definitions: defeat someone thoroughly in a contest or conflict situation
examples: The underdog team worsted the champions in yesterday's surprising match
She worsted her opponent in the final round of debate

definitions: inflict a physical injury on someone, especially with a weapon
cause emotional or psychological pain or distress to someone
examples: The soldier was wounded by shrapnel during the artillery bombardment
The hunter accidentally wounded the deer but couldn't track it
His harsh criticism deeply wounded her professional pride and confidence
The betrayal wounded him more than any physical injury could

definitions: impress or excite someone greatly through extraordinary quality or performance
examples: The magician's final trick really wowed the entire audience tonight
She wowed the judges with her powerful singing voice

definitions: cover or enclose something in paper, cloth, or other material
complete the filming or recording of a movie or show
encircle or surround something completely with arms or material
examples: She carefully wrapped each gift in colorful holiday paper
Could you wrap this sandwich in aluminum foil please?
The director announced they would wrap the movie next Friday
We wrapped the commercial shoot earlier than expected yesterday
The snake wrapped itself around the thick tree branch
She wrapped her arms around him in a warm embrace

definitions: cause or inflict great damage, harm, or destruction upon something
examples: The hurricane wreaked havoc on the coastal communities last night
The invasive species wreaked devastation on the local ecosystem

definitions: destroy or severely damage something through violent impact or action
cause a ship to be destroyed or sink, especially on rocks
examples: The drunk driver wrecked three parked cars before stopping
The demolition crew will wreck the old building tomorrow morning
The storm wrecked several vessels along the rocky coastline
Pirates deliberately wrecked ships to plunder their valuable cargo

definitions: pull or twist something suddenly and violently away from position
injure a joint or muscle by sudden twisting or pulling movement
distort or misrepresent the meaning or interpretation of something
examples: She wrenched the door open despite the rusty hinges protesting
He wrenched the weapon from the attacker's grip forcefully
I wrenched my ankle stepping off the curb this morning
The gymnast wrenched her shoulder during the difficult routine
Don't wrench my words out of their intended context please
The media wrenched his statement to create sensational headlines

definitions: forcibly pull or take something from a person's grasp or control
obtain something with difficulty or effort from a reluctant source
examples: The hero wrested the sword from the villain's iron grip
Rebels wrested control of the capital from government forces
She finally wrested an apology from her stubborn colleague
Scientists wrested new insights from the complex data patterns

definitions: engage in physical combat by grappling and trying to throw opponent
struggle mentally with a difficult problem, decision, or challenge
examples: The two athletes wrestled for the championship title last night
Children often wrestle playfully on the living room floor
She wrestled with the moral implications of her difficult decision
He's been wrestling with this mathematical proof for several weeks

definitions: develop small lines or folds, especially on skin or fabric
cause something to develop small lines, folds, or creases
examples: Her forehead wrinkles whenever she concentrates on difficult problems
This fabric wrinkles easily in humid weather conditions
Don't wrinkle your dress before the important photo shoot
Years of sun exposure wrinkled his weathered face prematurely

definitions: mark letters, words, or symbols on a surface with an instrument
compose and produce a text, book, article, or other written work
create computer program code or software using programming languages
examples: Please write your name clearly on the application form
The child learned to write the alphabet in kindergarten class
She writes mystery novels that consistently top bestseller lists
He wrote a heartfelt letter to his daughter yesterday
The developer writes clean, efficient code for mobile applications
Can you write a script to automate this repetitive task?

definitions: make a photographic copy of a document using a photocopying machine
examples: Could you xerox these contracts for everyone attending the meeting?
She xeroxed all the receipts for her expense report

definitions: sail in a yacht, especially for pleasure or as a sport
examples: They yacht around the Mediterranean every summer for two months
The wealthy couple yachts to different Caribbean islands each winter

definitions: talk persistently or chatter about trivial or boring matters at length
examples: She yakked on the phone for three hours straight yesterday
The neighbors yak endlessly about their vacation plans constantly

definitions: pull something with a sudden, sharp, forceful movement or jerk
examples: She yanked the door open when it stuck halfway
The dentist yanked out the stubborn tooth in one motion

definitions: give a sharp, shrill bark, especially repeatedly by small dogs
examples: The tiny dog yapped at every passing car incessantly
The puppies yapped excitedly when their owner returned home

definitions: tell long or implausible stories, especially in an entertaining way
examples: The old sailor yarned about his adventures at sea
Grandfather would yarn for hours about his youth adventures

definitions: of a ship or aircraft, deviate unsteadily from intended course
examples: The ship yawed dangerously in the severe storm conditions
The small plane yawed to the left in strong crosswinds

definitions: shout something or make a loud, sharp cry, especially in anger
examples: She yelled for help when she saw the accident
The coach yelled instructions from the sideline throughout the game

definitions: become yellow in color, especially with age or exposure
cause something to become yellow through aging or chemical process
examples: The pages of the old book yellowed over many decades
His teeth yellowed from years of smoking cigarettes daily
The sun yellowed the white curtains hanging in the window
Time and neglect had yellowed the once-white wedding dress

definitions: make a short, sharp cry, especially of pain, surprise, or alarm
examples: The dog yelped when someone accidentally stepped on its tail
She yelped in surprise when the cold water hit her

definitions: have a strong desire or longing for something or someone
examples: She's been yenning for adventure since graduating from college
He yens to return to his childhood home someday

definitions: produce or provide a natural, agricultural, or industrial product
give way to arguments, demands, or pressure from others
relinquish possession or control of something to another
examples: The apple trees yielded an abundant harvest this year
This investment yields a five percent annual return consistently
She finally yielded to their persistent requests for help
The old bridge yielded under the weight of heavy traffic
The defeated army yielded the fortress to enemy forces
He yielded his seat to the elderly woman politely

definitions: give a short, sharp, high-pitched bark or cry
examples: The excited puppy yipped when it saw its favorite toy
Coyotes yipped in the distance throughout the desert night

definitions: sing with rapid alternation between normal voice and falsetto
examples: The Swiss mountain guide yodeled to demonstrate the echo
She learned to yodel from her grandmother in Austria

definitions: join or link two things or people together in partnership
attach a wooden crosspiece to animals for pulling loads together
examples: The treaty yoked the two nations in military alliance
The marriage yoked together two powerful business families permanently
The farmer yoked the oxen to plow the large field
They yoked the horses to pull the heavy wagon

definitions: strike suddenly with electricity, laser, or focused energy
destroy, kill, or obliterate something quickly and completely
cook or heat food quickly in a microwave oven
examples: The bug zapper zapped mosquitoes all night long effectively
Lightning zapped the old oak tree during the storm
The new software zaps viruses before they can spread
The laser treatment zapped the tumor cells completely
Just zap the leftovers in the microwave for two minutes
She zapped her coffee to warm it up again

definitions: adjust an instrument or device to show zero reading
direct one's attention precisely toward a specific target or goal
examples: Zero the scale before weighing each ingredient carefully
The technician zeroed the measuring device before testing began
The detective zeroed in on the prime suspect quickly
We need to zero in on our main objectives

definitions: add enthusiasm, energy, or excitement to an activity or situation
examples: Her lively personality zests up any boring office meeting
Music zests the atmosphere at their dinner parties wonderfully

definitions: move in a pattern of sharp turns alternating left and right
examples: The rabbit zigzagged across the field to escape predators
The mountain road zigzags up the steep cliff face

definitions: fasten or close something with a zipper or sliding fastener
move very quickly with energy or speed through space
compress computer files into a smaller archive format for storage
examples: She zipped up her jacket against the cold wind
Please zip your bag before going through airport security
The motorcycle zipped past us on the highway dangerously
Children zipped around the playground during recess time
Can you zip these files before sending them via email?
The program automatically zips large attachments to save space

definitions: fasten or close something using a zipper fastening device
examples: She zippered her dress carefully to avoid catching the fabric
The mechanic zippered his coveralls before starting work

definitions: divide an area into zones for particular purposes or uses
designate or mark an area for specific use or development
examples: The city zoned this area for commercial development only
They zoned the neighborhood to preserve its residential character
Officials zoned the wetlands as a protected wildlife habitat
The committee zoned several blocks for mixed-use development

definitions: move or travel very quickly with a loud humming sound
change the focal length of a camera lens for magnification
increase or rise rapidly and suddenly in amount or value
examples: The sports car zoomed past at incredible speed yesterday
Jets zoomed overhead during the military air show
The photographer zoomed in on the eagle's nest carefully
Can you zoom out to show the entire building?
Sales zoomed after the viral marketing campaign launched successfully
Stock prices zoomed to record highs this quarter

definitions: express pleasure, satisfaction, or sudden understanding through vocal sound
examples: The audience aahed at the spectacular fireworks display overhead
She aahed with delight when she opened the surprise gift

definitions: leave a place, person, or thing permanently with no intention of returning
cease to support, maintain, or continue with an activity or belief
allow oneself to indulge fully in a powerful emotion or desire
examples: They abandoned the sinking ship just before it capsized
The family abandoned their home during the wildfire evacuation
Scientists abandoned the theory after discovering contradictory evidence
She abandoned her medical studies to pursue art full-time
He abandoned himself to grief after losing his wife
The dancers abandoned themselves to the rhythm completely

definitions: become less intense, violent, or severe over a period of time
make something less intense, or reduce in degree, amount, or severity
examples: The storm finally abated after three days of destruction
Her anger gradually abated as she heard his explanation
The medication helped abate his chronic pain significantly
New regulations will abate pollution from industrial sources

definitions: formally relinquish monarchical power, throne, or high office
fail to fulfill or refuse to accept responsibility or duty
examples: The king abdicated in favor of his eldest son
Edward VIII abdicated to marry Wallis Simpson in 1936
Parents who abdicate their responsibilities harm their children's development
The manager abdicated his duty to supervise the project

definitions: take someone away illegally by force or deception, typically for ransom
examples: The criminals abducted the businessman from his office parking lot
Aliens supposedly abducted him according to his strange story

definitions: encourage, support, or help someone to commit a crime or wrongdoing
examples: She was charged with abetting the fugitive's escape attempt
Anyone who abets tax evasion faces serious legal consequences

definitions: accept or tolerate something unpleasant or someone's behavior patiently
remain in a place or continue in a particular condition
accept and act in accordance with a rule, decision, or recommendation
examples: I cannot abide his constant complaining about trivial matters
She couldn't abide the noise from the construction site
These traditions abide despite centuries of social change
His love for her abides through all their difficulties
All students must abide by the school's code of conduct
Citizens are expected to abide by the court's decision

definitions: formally put an end to a system, practice, institution, or law
examples: Lincoln abolished slavery with the Emancipation Proclamation in 1863
Many countries have abolished capital punishment in recent decades

definitions: deliberately terminate a human pregnancy before the fetus is viable
cancel or abandon a mission, project, or planned operation prematurely
fail to complete development or come to nothing before completion
examples: The doctor advised her to abort due to medical complications
They decided to abort the pregnancy in the first trimester
NASA aborted the launch due to unexpected weather conditions
The pilot aborted takeoff when the warning light appeared
The software aborted the installation process due to errors
Their plans aborted when funding suddenly became unavailable

definitions: exist in large numbers or amounts, be plentiful or very common
examples: Wildlife abounds in this protected national forest reserve area
Opportunities abound for those willing to work hard consistently
